sections.title: Retain Some Layers In The Selected Page
sections.context:
Retain Some Layers In The Selected Page
, you'll be prompted to
choose which Visio layers to include.
1.
Click

sections.title: Convert To Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Convert To Adobe PDF
, specify a location and filename, and click
Save
.

sections.title: Select Visio layers to convert (Acrobat Pro)
sections.context:
Select Visio layers to convert (Acrobat Pro)
You can convert a Visio drawing that contains layers to a PDF and retain some or all of the
layers in the resulting PDF, or you can flatten the layers. You can also organize the Visio layers
in
layer sets
, which are folders in the

sections.title: Acrobat Layers
sections.context:
Acrobat Layers
panel.
1.
With the multilayered file open in Visio, click a button in the

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
toolbar, and
select

sections.title: Retain Some Layers In The Selected Page
sections.context:
Retain Some Layers In The Selected Page
.
Note:
If the

sections.title: Retain Some Layers In The Selected Page
sections.context:
Retain Some Layers In The Selected Page
option is not available, deselect
the

sections.title: Convert All Pages In Drawing
sections.context:
Convert All Pages In Drawing
option.
2.
Select one or more layers in the

sections.title: Layers In Visio Drawing
sections.context:
Layers In Visio Drawing
list.
3.
To add the selected Visio layers to the list of layers to convert to the PDF file, do one
of the following:
*
To convert the selected Visio layers to individual PDF layers within a PDF layer
set, click

sections.title: Create Layer Set
sections.context:
Create Layer Set
, and optionally, type a layer name.
*
To convert the selected Visio layers to individual layers (but not grouped
under a layer set), click the
Add Layer(s)
button.
Note:
The name of a layer in the

sections.title: Layers In Visio Drawing
sections.context:
Layers In Visio Drawing
list is unavailable if that
layer is included in the

sections.title: Layers In PDF
sections.context:
Layers In PDF
list. When you select that layer in the

sections.title: Layers In
sections.context:
Layers In
PDF
list, a bullet appears next to the layer's name in the

sections.title: Layers In Visio Drawing
sections.context:
Layers In Visio Drawing
list.
4.
Optionally, do any of the following:
*
To reorder the layers in the

sections.title: Layers In PDF
sections.context:
Layers In PDF
list, drag an item up or down in the
list.
*
To include a visibility property that can be switched on or off in Acrobat,
deselect

sections.title: Locked On
sections.context:
Locked On
adjacent to the PDF layer; to lock the resulting PDF layer's
visibility on, select

sections.title: Locked On
sections.context:
Locked On
.
*
To save the current settings of Visio layers selected, click

sections.title: Save PDF Settings
sections.context:
Save PDF Settings
,
and click
OK
. These settings are used the next time you convert the current
Visio file to a PDF file.
5.
Click

sections.title: Convert To PDF
sections.context:
Convert To PDF
, specify a folder in the
Save In
box in which to save the PDF file,
type a filename, and then click
Save
.

sections.title: Visio layers that were selected for conversion and that have Visio settings for
sections.context:
Note:
Visio layers that were selected for conversion and that have Visio settings for
visible, printable, or lock are converted to PDF layers; the visible and printable
properties are included in the resulting PDF layers. If the Visio file contains a
background page, header, or footer, the PDF file automatically has PDF layers named
for those items.

sections.title: Convert AutoCAD files to PDF (Acrobat Pro for
sections.context: Convert AutoCAD files to PDF (Acrobat Pro for

sections.title: Windows)
sections.context:
Windows)
Use PDFMaker to convert AutoCAD files from within the AutoCAD application. You can also use
the

sections.title: Batch Conversion
sections.context:
Batch Conversion
feature to convert many AutoCAD files in one operation.
Acrobat
PDFMaker preserves selected layers and layouts when converting AutoCAD files to PDF.

sections.title: Convert AutoCAD files when AutoCAD is installed
sections.context:
Convert AutoCAD files when AutoCAD is installed
When converting individual AutoCAD files, you don't usually need to change page size and
plotting settings. PDFMaker uses the appropriate layout page size and plotting information to
create a correctly sized PDF file.
Note:
Acrobat can't convert DWG to PDF without AutoCAD installed.
1.
To change the PDF conversion settings, choose

sections.title: Change Conversion
sections.context:
Change Conversion
Settings
in AutoCAD.
2.
Do one of the following:
*
Click a button in the

sections.title: Convert To Adobe
sections.context:
Convert To Adobe
PDF
or

sections.title: Convert To Adobe PDFAnd Send For Review
sections.context:
Convert To Adobe PDFAnd Send For Review
.
*
Choose

sections.title: Convert To Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Convert To Adobe PDF
.
*
Choose

sections.title: Convert To Adobe PDF And Email
sections.context:
Convert To Adobe PDF And Email
.
*
Choose

sections.title: Convert To Adobe PDFAnd Send For Review
sections.context:
Convert To Adobe PDFAnd Send For Review
.
3.
In the

sections.title: Choose Layouts
sections.context:
Choose Layouts
dialog box, add or remove layouts as needed. To reorder the
layouts, select a layout from the

sections.title: Layouts In PDF
sections.context:
Layouts In PDF
list, and click
Move Up
or
Move
Down
.
4.
To determine how the AutoCAD layers are converted, select one of the following, and
then click
Continue
:
*

sections.title: Flatten All Layers
sections.context:
Flatten All Layers
. When layers are flattened, only those entities belonging to
layers that are not frozen and are printable appear in the converted PDF.
*

sections.title: Retain All Or Some Layers
sections.context:
Retain All Or Some Layers
. In the next dialog box, specify the layers to include
in the resulting PDF.
5.
Specify a filename and location in the
Save As
dialog box, and click
Save
.

sections.title: Select AutoCAD layers to convert
sections.context:
Select AutoCAD layers to convert
If you choose to retain all or some AutoCAD layers when converting to PDF, you can specify
which layers are preserved in the PDF.
1.
In AutoCAD, start to convert an AutoCAD file and select the

sections.title: Retain All Or Some
sections.context:
Retain All Or Some
Layers
option.
2.
To show specific AutoCAD layers in the

sections.title: Layers In Drawing
sections.context:
Layers In Drawing
list, do any of the
following:
*
Choose an option from the

sections.title: Named Layer Filters
sections.context:
Named Layer Filters
menu to list all layers that fit
that criterion.
*
Select the
Invert
option to list all layers except those layers that are described
by the selected choice in the

sections.title: Named Layer Filters
sections.context:
Named Layer Filters
menu.
*
To change the sort order of the layers, click the headings.
Note:
To change the
On
,
Frozen
, or
Plot
properties for a layer, click
Cancel
, change
the properties in the AutoCAD drawing, and restart the procedure.
3.
To select the AutoCAD layers to convert, do any of the following:
*
Choose a previously saved set of layers from the

sections.title: PDF Layer Settings
sections.context:
PDF Layer Settings
menu.
*
Select one or more layers from the

sections.title: Layers In Drawing
sections.context:
Layers In Drawing
List.
*
To convert all of the layers in the drawing, click

sections.title: Add All Layers
sections.context:
Add All Layers
, and go to step
5.
4.
To add the selected AutoCAD layers to the

sections.title: Layers In PDF
sections.context:
Layers In PDF
list, do one of the following:
*
To convert the selected AutoCAD layers to individual layers within a PDF layer
set, click

sections.title: Create Layer Set
sections.context:
Create Layer Set
. This action creates a folder of layers in
the
Layers
navigation pane in Acrobat.
*
To convert the selected AutoCAD layers to individual layers, click
Add
Layer(s)
.
5.
Optionally, do any of the following in the

sections.title: Layers In PDF
sections.context:
Layers In PDF
list:
*
To reorder layers, drag an item up or down in the list.
*
To include a visibility property that can be switched on or off in Acrobat,
deselect

sections.title: Locked On
sections.context:
Locked On
for the PDF layer. To lock the resulting PDF layer's
visibility on, select

sections.title: Locked On
sections.context:
Locked On
.
*
To save the current list of selected AutoCAD layers, click

sections.title: Add PDF Setting
sections.context:
Add PDF Setting
.
Later, you can retrieve this list from the

sections.title: PDF Layer Settings
sections.context:
PDF Layer Settings
menu.
6.
Click
Convert
, specify a filename and location, and then click
Save
.

sections.title: Convert AutoCAD files in batches
sections.context:
Convert AutoCAD files in batches
1.
Choose

sections.title: Batch Conversion
sections.context:
Batch Conversion
.
2.
Specify your preferences for layers, page size, plot style, and output PDFs.
Click

sections.title: Conversion Settings
sections.context:
Conversion Settings
to specify the

sections.title: Acrobat PDFMaker
sections.context:
Acrobat PDFMaker
settings.
3.
In the DWG List, do any of the following:
*
Click

sections.title: Add Files
sections.context:
Add Files
, and then specify the folder or files.
*
To load a previously saved list of files, click

sections.title: Append List
sections.context:
Append List
, and then specify the
list.
*
As needed, expand individual files and select or deselect the items you want,
such as model space and layouts. To exclude or include all model space, click
the associated buttons.
*
To exclude a file from the conversion, deselect the file box. As needed, select
or deselect all of the files in the list, change the order of the files, remove files,
or clear the list.
*
To show the complete file paths, select
Expand File Name(s)
.
*
To save the DWG list for later use, click

sections.title: Save List
sections.context:
Save List
. This action saves the list in
its current state, including the file order and file selections. You can retrieve
this list at any time by clicking

sections.title: Append List
sections.context:
Append List
.
4.
Click
Convert
.
5.
Once the conversion has finished, you can click

sections.title: Save Details
sections.context:
Save Details
to save a log file of the
conversion.

sections.title: Application-specific PDFMaker settings
sections.context:
Application-specific PDFMaker settings
Sometimes the conversion settings in one PDFMaker-enabled application are different from the
settings in a different application.
Some PDFMaker settings are common to several or most applications. Some options are unique
to a specific application.

sections.title: Settings tab options available from within most applications
sections.context:
Settings tab options available from within most applications
The following settings appear on the
Settings
tab available from within most PDFMaker-
enabled applications.

sections.title: Attach Source File
sections.context:
Attach Source File
Includes the document being converted as an attachment to the PDF.

sections.title: Create Bookmarks
sections.context:
Create Bookmarks
Converts certain elements in original Office documents to PDF bookmarks: Word headings,
Excel worksheet names, or PowerPoint titles. Selecting this option overrides any settings on
the

sections.title: Conversion Settings
sections.context:
Conversion Settings
dialog box.

sections.title: Add Links
sections.context:
Add Links
Includes active links and hypertext in the PDF.
Note:
If this option is deselected, but the recipient of the PDF has the create Links From URLs
preference selected, URLs in the PDF are still active.

sections.title: Enable Accessibility And Reflow With Tagged Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Enable Accessibility And Reflow With Tagged Adobe PDF
Embeds tags in the PDF.

sections.title: Excel-specific options on the Settings tab
sections.context: Excel-specific options on the Settings tab

sections.title: Convert Comments
sections.context:
Convert Comments
Converts user-created Excel comments to notes and lists them in the Acrobat

sections.title: Actual Size
sections.context:
Actual Size
Uses actual size specified in the worksheet. Worksheets are not resized.

sections.title: Fit Worksheet To A Single Page
sections.context: Fit Worksheet To A Single Page

sections.title: Fit To Paper Width
sections.context:
Fit To Paper Width
Adjusts the width of each worksheet so that all the columns on that worksheet appear on one
page in the PDF.

sections.title: Prompt For Selecting Excel Sheets
sections.context:
Prompt For Selecting Excel Sheets
Opens a dialog box at the beginning of the file conversion process. In this dialog box, you can
specify which worksheets are included in the PDF and the order in which the sheets appear in
the PDF.

sections.title: PowerPoint-specific options on the Settings tab
sections.context: PowerPoint-specific options on the Settings tab

sections.title: Preserve Slide Transitions
sections.context:
Preserve Slide Transitions
Converts PowerPoint slide transition effects to PDF transition effects.

sections.title: Convert Hidden Slides To PDF Pages
sections.context:
Convert Hidden Slides To PDF Pages
Converts any PowerPoint slides that are not seen in the usual playing of the presentation to
PDF pages.

sections.title: Convert Speaker Notes
sections.context:
Convert Speaker Notes
Converts any speaker notes for the PowerPoint presentation into Text notes in the PDF.

sections.title: Email-specific options on the Settings tab
sections.context:
Email-specific options on the Settings tab
The following options appear when you open the PDFMaker settings from within Microsoft
Outlook or Lotus Notes.

sections.title: Compatibility
sections.context:
Compatibility
Sets the compatibility level of the PDF. Use the most recent version (in this case, version 1.7
ADBE-3) to include all the latest features and functionality. If you're creating PDFs that are
distributed widely, choose an earlier level to ensure that all users can view and print the
document.

sections.title: Attachments
sections.context:
Attachments
Indicates whether all files attached to email messages are included in the PDF.

sections.title: Output Adobe PDF Portfolio When Creating A New PDF File
sections.context:
Output Adobe PDF Portfolio When Creating A New PDF File
When selected, always converts individual messages as component files of a

sections.title: PDF Portfolio
sections.context:
PDF Portfolio
.
When deselected, merges individual messages as separate pages of a PDF.

sections.title: Do Not Include Folder Name Information
sections.context:
Do Not Include Folder Name Information
When selected, excludes mail folder names from PDFs.

sections.title: Embed Index For Faster Search
sections.context:
Embed Index For Faster Search
Creates an embedded index, which speeds up searches, especially when you convert large
numbers of email messages or message folders.

sections.title: Block Download Of External Content
sections.context:
Block Download Of External Content
When selected, prevents the downloading of any external Internet content, such as images,
CSS, and JavaScript.

sections.title: Page Layout options
sections.context:
Page Layout options
Specifies page properties, like the properties found in the Print dialog box: page dimensions,
orientation, and margins.
Show This Number Of Recent Archives (Outlook only)
When converting email messages and folders, the

sections.title: Convert Selected Folders
Show "Attach As Adobe PDF" Buttons
sections.context:
Show "Attach As Adobe PDF" Buttons
If selected, the

sections.title: Attach As Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Attach As Adobe PDF
button appears in the Outlook email message window.

sections.title: AutoCAD-specific options on the Settings tab (Acrobat Pro)
sections.context:
AutoCAD-specific options on the Settings tab (Acrobat Pro)
The following options appear when you open the PDFMaker settings from within Autodesk
AutoCAD.

sections.title: Compliance Standard
sections.context:
Compliance Standard
Specify the PDF/A or PDF/E compliance standard, or none.

sections.title: Open Layers Pane When Viewed In Acrobat
sections.context:
Open Layers Pane When Viewed In Acrobat
Shows the layers structure when a PDF is opened in Acrobat.

sections.title: Embed Scale Information
sections.context:
Embed Scale Information
Preserves drawing-scale information, which is usable with the Acrobat measurement tools.

sections.title: Do Not Convert Model Space To 3D
sections.context:
Do Not Convert Model Space To 3D
When selected, the model space layout is not converted to a 3D annotation in the PDF.

sections.title: Choose Layout Option
sections.context:
Choose Layout Option
Specifies whether

sections.title: Selected Layouts
sections.context:
Selected Layouts
are included in the PDF.

sections.title: Exclude Model Space
sections.context:
Exclude Model Space
(Available only when

sections.title: Convert All Layouts Without Prompting
sections.context:
Convert All Layouts Without Prompting
is selected from

sections.title: Choose Layout
sections.context:
Choose Layout
Option
.) When selected, all layouts except the model space are included in the PDF.

sections.title: Choose Layer Option
sections.context:
Choose Layer Option
Specifies whether

sections.title: No Layers
sections.context:
No Layers
are included as layers in the PDF.

sections.title: Visio-specific options on the Settings tab (Acrobat Pro)
sections.context:
Visio-specific options on the Settings tab (Acrobat Pro)
The following options appear when you open the PDFMaker settings from within Microsoft
Visio.

sections.title: Include Visio Custom Properties As Object Data In The Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Include Visio Custom Properties As Object Data In The Adobe PDF
Indicates whether custom properties of the Visio image are included as object data in the new
PDF.

sections.title: Exclude Visio Objects With No Custom Properties
sections.context:
Exclude Visio Objects With No Custom Properties
Indicates whether the new PDF excludes Visio objects without custom properties.

sections.title: Convert Comments To Adobe PDF Comments
sections.context:
Convert Comments To Adobe PDF Comments
Indicates whether the comments in the Visio file are converted to PDF comments in the new
PDF.

sections.title: Always Flatten Layers In Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Always Flatten Layers In Adobe PDF
Specifies if the layers are flattened. If you flatten layers, the PDF looks like the original drawing,
but doesn't contain any layer information. All shapes in the Visio drawing are converted,
regardless of their protection or behavior, and shape custom properties can be converted to
PDF object data.

sections.title: Open Layers Pane When Viewed In Acrobat
sections.context:
Open Layers Pane When Viewed In Acrobat
Shows the layers structure when a PDF is opened in Acrobat.

sections.title: Word tab settings (Microsoft Word)
sections.context: Word tab settings (Microsoft Word)

sections.title: Convert Displayed Comments To Notes In Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Convert Displayed Comments To Notes In Adobe PDF
Changes any Word comment entries to PDF comments. If the currently open Word document
contains comments, more options appear in the

sections.title: Comments
sections.context:
Comments
list on this tab:

sections.title: Reviewer
sections.context:
Reviewer
Lists the names of reviewers who have entered comments in the current Word document.

sections.title: Notes Open
sections.context:
Notes Open
Specifies whether the PDF comment windows automatically open or are closed for that
reviewer's comments.
Color
Shows the color for that reviewer's comment icons. Clicking the color icon repeatedly cycles
through a limited set of available colors.
# Of Comments
Shows the number of comments that the reviewer made.

sections.title: Convert Footnote And Endnote Links
sections.context:
Convert Footnote And Endnote Links
Integrates these into the PDF.

sections.title: Convert signature fields specified by pdfmarks
sections.context:
Convert signature fields specified by pdfmarks
Converts signature fields indicated by pdfmarks.

sections.title: Enable Advanced Tagging
sections.context:
Enable Advanced Tagging
Integrates this into the PDF.

sections.title: Bookmarks tab settings (Microsoft Word)
sections.context:
Bookmarks tab settings (Microsoft Word)
The options you specify on this tab determine which items are converted into PDF bookmarks
in the PDF.
Note:
To include bookmarks in the conversion process, you must select the

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
option on the
Settings
tab. If you deselect that option, you override any options you
select on this tab, and no bookmarks are created.

sections.title: Convert Word Headings To Bookmarks
sections.context:
Convert Word Headings To Bookmarks
Selects all the headings in the

sections.title: Elements
sections.context:
Elements
list for conversion to PDF bookmarks.

sections.title: Convert Word Styles To Bookmarks
sections.context:
Convert Word Styles To Bookmarks
Selects all the text styles in the

sections.title: Elements
sections.context:
Elements
list for conversion to PDF bookmarks (deselected by
default).

sections.title: Convert Word Bookmarks
sections.context:
Convert Word Bookmarks
Converts any user-created Word bookmarks to PDF bookmarks.

sections.title: Headings
sections.context:
Headings
and
Styles
indicate the element types.
Type
Also indicates whether the element is a heading or style in the Word document.

sections.title: Bookmark
sections.context:
Bookmark
Displays X's, indicating whether individual elements are converted to PDF bookmarks. Clicking
an individual

sections.title: Bookmark
sections.context:
Bookmark
option changes the selection status for that element.
Level
Specifies where the element fits in the hierarchy structure of the PDF

sections.title: Bookmarks
sections.context:
Bookmarks
panel.
Clicking an individual
Level
number opens a menu that you can use to change the value.
Note:
When some but not all of the available Word headings and styles are selected for conversion to
PDF bookmarks, the marker in the corresponding check boxes at the top of the tab change. If all
elements of the type are selected, a check mark appears. If only some of the elements of that
type are selected, a colored square appears. Otherwise, the check box is empty.

sections.title: Create PDFs by printing to file
sections.context:
Create PDFs by printing to file
In many authoring applications, you can use the Print command with the Adobe PDF printer to
convert your file to PDF. Your source document is converted to PostScript and fed directly to
Distiller for conversion to PDF, without manually starting Distiller. The current Distiller
preference settings and Adobe PDF settings are used to convert the file. If you're working with
nonstandard page sizes, create a custom page size.
Note:
(Windows) For Microsoft Office documents, the

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
printer does not include some of
the features that are available from PDFMaker. For example, you cannot create bookmarks and
hyperlinks using the

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
printer. If you're creating a PDF from a

sections.title: Microsoft
sections.context:
Microsoft
Office
document and you want to use these features, use PDFMaker.
The

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
printer creates untagged PDFs. A tagged structure is required for reflowing
content to a handheld device and is preferable for producing reliable results with a screen
reader.

sections.title: Create a PDF using the Print command (Windows)
sections.context:
Create a PDF using the Print command (Windows)
1.
Open the file in its authoring application, and choose File > Print.
2.
Choose

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
from the printers menu.
3.
Click the Properties (or Preferences) button to customize the

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
printer
setting. (In some applications, you may need to click Setup in the Print dialog box to
open the list of printers, and then click Properties or Preferences.)
4.
In the Print dialog box, click OK.
Note:
Your PDF is saved in the folder specified by the setting of the
Adobe
PDF
Output Folder in the Preferences dialog box; the default location is My
Documents. If you specify Prompt For Adobe PDF Filename, then a
Save As
dialog
opens when you print.

sections.title: Create a PDF using the Print command (Mac OS X)
sections.context:
Create a PDF using the Print command (Mac OS X)
The method for creating PDFs using the Print command changed in
Mac OS
v10.6
Snow
Leopard
with Acrobat 9.1 and later. The following procedure describes the method in both
Snow Leopard and earlier versions of
Mac OS
X.
1.
Open the file in its authoring application, and choose File > Print.

sections.title: Save As Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Save As Adobe PDF
from the PDF menu at the bottom of the dialog box.
3.
For

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
Settings, choose one of the default settings, or customize the settings
using Distiller. Any custom settings that you have defined are listed.
For most users, the default

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
conversion settings are adequate.
4.
For After PDF Creation, specify whether to open the PDF.
5.
Click Continue.
6.
Select a name and location for your PDF, and click Save.
Note:
By default, your PDF is saved with the same filename and a .pdf extension.

sections.title: Adobe PDF printing preferences (Windows)
sections.context:
Adobe PDF printing preferences (Windows)
Printing preferences apply to all applications that use the

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
printer, unless you change
the settings in an authoring application by using the

sections.title: Document Setup
sections.context:
Document Setup
, or Print
menu.
Note:
The dialog box for setting printing preferences is named

sections.title: Adobe PDFPrinting Preferences
sections.context:
Adobe PDFPrinting Preferences
,
Adobe PDF Printing Defaults, or

sections.title: Adobe PDFDocument Properties
sections.context:
Adobe PDFDocument Properties
, depending on how you
access it.
To access printing preferences:
*
Open the Printers window from the Start menu. Right-click the

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
printer, and
choose

sections.title: Printing Preferences
sections.context:
Printing Preferences
.
*
In an authoring application such as Adobe InDesign, choose File > Print. Select
Adobe
PDF
as the printer, and click the Properties (or Preferences) button. (In some
applications, you may need to click Setup in the Print dialog box to access the list of
printers, and then click Properties or Preferences to customize the

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
settings.)
PDF-specific options appear on the

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
Settings tab. The

sections.title: Paper Quality
sections.context:
Paper Quality
tab and Layout
tab contain other familiar options for the paper source, printer ink, page orientation, and
number of pages per sheet.

sections.title: Adobe PDFConversion Settings
sections.context:
Adobe PDFConversion Settings
Select a predefined set of options from the

sections.title: Default Settings
sections.context:
Default Settings
menu or click Edit to view or
change the settings in the

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
Settings dialog box.

sections.title: Adobe PDF Security
sections.context:
Adobe PDF Security
To add security to the PDF, choose one of the following options, or click Edit to view or change
the security settings:
*

sections.title: Reconfirm Security For Each Job
sections.context:
Reconfirm Security For Each Job
: Opens the Adobe PDF Security dialog box each time
you create a PDF using the Adobe PDF printer. Specify the desired settings in the dialog
box.
*
Use The Last Known Security Settings:
Uses the same security settings that were used
the last time a PDF was created using the Adobe PDF printer on your computer.

sections.title: Adobe PDF Output Folder
sections.context: Adobe PDF Output Folder

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
Filename to specify a location and filename at the time
of conversion.

sections.title: Adobe PDF Page Size menu
sections.context:
Adobe PDF Page Size menu
Select a custom page size that you have defined.

sections.title: Replace Existing PDF
sections.context:
Replace Existing PDF
Choose if you want to replace the existing PDF
Always
,
Ask Everytime,
or
Never
replace.

sections.title: View Adobe PDF Results
sections.context:
View Adobe PDF Results
Automatically starts Acrobat and displays the converted document immediately.

sections.title: Add Document Information
sections.context:
Add Document Information
Includes information such as the filename and date and time of creation.

sections.title: Rely On System Fonts Only; Do Not Use Document Fonts
sections.context:
Rely On System Fonts Only; Do Not Use Document Fonts
Deselect this option to download fonts when creating the PDF. All your fonts will be available in
the PDF, but it will take longer to create it. Leave this option selected if you are working with
Asian-language documents.

sections.title: Delete Log Files For Successful Jobs
sections.context:
Delete Log Files For Successful Jobs
Automatically deletes the log files unless the job fails.

sections.title: Set Adobe PDF printer properties (Windows)
sections.context: Set Adobe PDF printer properties (Windows)

sections.title: In Windows
sections.context:
In Windows
, you can usually leave the

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
printer properties unchanged, unless you
have configured printer sharing or set security.
Note:
Printing Properties are different from printer Preferences. The Properties dialog box contains
tabs of options that apply to any type of printer; the Preferences include conversion options
specifically for the

sections.title: Set Adobe PDF printer properties
sections.context:
Set Adobe PDF printer properties
1.
Open

sections.title: Devices and Printers
sections.context:
Devices and Printers
from the Start menu, and right-click the
Adobe
PDF
printer.
2.
Choose Properties.
3.
Click the tabs, and select options as needed.

sections.title: Reassign the port that the Adobe PDF printer uses
sections.context:
Reassign the port that the Adobe PDF printer uses
1.
Quit Distiller if it is running, and allow all queued jobs to the

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
printer to
complete.
2.
Open

sections.title: Devices and Printers
sections.context:
Devices and Printers
from the Start menu.
3.
Right-click the

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
printer, and choose

sections.title: Printer Properties
sections.context:
Printer Properties
.
4.
Click the Ports tab, and then click Add Port.
5.
Select

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
Port (Windows XP) or

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
Port Monitor (Vista/Windows 7)
from the list of available port types, and click New Port.
6.
Select a local folder for PDF output files, and click OK. Then click Close to quit the
Printer Ports dialog box.
7.
In the

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
Properties dialog box, click Apply, and then click OK.
Note:
For best results, select a folder on the same system where Distiller is installed.
Although remote or network folders are supported, they have limited user access and
security issues.

sections.title: Delete a folder and reassign the Adobe PDF printer to the default port
sections.context: Delete a folder and reassign the Adobe PDF printer to the default port

sections.title: Devices and Printers
sections.context:
Devices and Printers
from the Start menu.
3.
Right-click the

sections.title: Adobe PDF
sections.context:
Adobe PDF
printer, and choose

sections.title: Printer Properties
sections.context:
Printer Properties
.
4.
Click the Ports tab.
5.
Select the default port, Documents, and click Apply.
6.
Select the port to delete, click Delete Port, and then click OK to confirm the deletion.
7.
Select the Documents port again and click Close.
